awd_abstract_narration:
This is a proposal to create an I-Corps Site at the University of Connecticut (UConn).

NSF Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. 

I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors.

The University of Connecticut proposes to create Accelerate UConn, an NSF I-Corp Site, to strengthen its existing innovation ecosystem with entrepreneurial education, experiential learning and a business creation process that is based on the I-Corps model. Accelerate UConn (AU) is a joint effort of Technology Acceleration Partners (TAP) ­UConn's technology transfer, incubation and commercialization entity -and the Connecticut Center for Entrepreneurship and Innovation (CCEI), which is responsible for much of UConn?s internal and external entrepreneurial education activities. 

As an NSF I-Corps site, AU will expand UConn's community of innovators and entrepreneurs and will aid in the transformation of UConn discoveries into products that benefit humanity and add to economic growth. 

Broader Impacts:
The proposed activity may significantly impact the preparedness of university talent for roles in technology-based, entrepreneurial enterprises and, as such, will be a critical ingredient of the economic success of Connecticut and the nation. Connecticut has historically relied on well-established companies to support its economy, resulting in a dearth of entrepreneurial talent that has lead to a loss of innovative capacity. AU's activities will support the shift from dependence on large corporate employers to an entrepreneurially driven economy. As more startups begin to flourish as a result of AU's efforts, new jobs will be created and the career prospects of  graduates will be strengthened. 

On the national level, there is valid concern that losing our standing as the global leader in technology will result in economic contraction. AU?s activities may counter this trend by teaching university researchers to think beyond traditional academic boundaries, thus enabling this group of individuals to remain in science by becoming drivers of innovation within technology-based, entrepreneurial companies, which they help to create.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The University of Connecticut is ranked amongst the nation?s top 25 universities and is a national leader among public research universities. Across 80 research centers and institutes, and 14 schools and colleges, UConn has over 2,000 active researchers who are internationally recognized for excellence in their fields. With a long history of innovation, UConn scholars have sparked economic impact through innovative discoveries and inventions. Since 2014, more than 500 inventions have been disclosed and more than 700 patents have been granted to UConn innovations. In 2020-2021, UConn received $375M in research funding and $68M from the NSF alone.

 

UConn was amongst the first 21 institutions awarded an NSF I-Corps site grant and since has trained eleven cohorts of the Accelerate UConn (site training) to over 170 teams across 18 cohorts. The site is facilitated by the Connecticut Center for Entrepreneurship & Innovation (CCEI) in partnership with Technology Commercialization Services with the mission of expanding the community of innovators and entrepreneurs. The goals of the initiative are to aid in the transformation of technologies into products and services that benefit economic growth and society as a whole, as well as connect the researchers and entrepreneurs leading these efforts with effective next step resources, mentorship, and funding opportunities.

 

Since launching Accelerate UConn in 2014, the program has leveraged existing infrastructure at the University to gain initial traction with key partners and potential participants. Existing commercialization efforts at UConn played a significant role in the program formation and pipeline of talent. This effort has since expanded the volume of activity in the form of proof of concept funding and support as well as additional grant opportunities. In addition to supporting commercialization of technology developed by faculty, Accelerate UConn supports post docs, graduate students, and undergraduate students as they have innovated new technology, products and services. 

 

Accelerate UConn has integrated itself into the initial phase of support in the innovation funnel at the University and it?s development opened up opportunities to support teams before and after the stage in which the program supported. In addition, it became clear that not all projects that came through the pipeline would have a basis in science or technology and that there was a need to support projects beyond what was offered through the program. Additionally, teams that completed the program that were ready to take their product to market were in need of support within the University. The CCEI Summer Fellowship program was developed to provide next step resources, mentorship, pro-bono professional services, and business development to these teams. This program has become the top entrepreneurial program at the University and is the only accelerator program offered on campus. Since 2015, Accelerate UConn teams have generated more than $50M in follow on funding in forms of grants (SBIR/STTR), investor funding, and revenue.

 

For a listing of news and other related program successes, please visit https://accelerate.uconn.edu/news/

 


Last Modified: 05/11/2022
Modified by: Jennifer E Mathieu
